title.value: Learning with Rejection for Abstractive Text Summarization
title.justification: The paper is titled 'Learning with Rejection for Abstractive Text Summarization.'
title.quote: Learning with Rejection for Abstractive Text Summarization

extractions.description: This paper proposes a new training objective and decoding objective for abstractive text summarization to improve the factuality of generated summaries. The training objective involves rejection learning to allow the model to reject unsupported text spans, and the decoding objective penalizes non-factual summaries using a regularization term. The proposed method is compared with five baseline models and shows significant improvement in both automatic and human evaluations.

type.justification: The paper primarily involves experimental comparisons and evaluations of different models and training objectives for abstractive text summarization.
type.quote: We show that our method considerably improves the factuality of generated summaries in automatic and human evaluations when compared to five baseline models.

name.justification: The primary focus of the paper is on abstractive text summarization, a sub-field of Natural Language Processing.
name.quote: State-of-the-art abstractive summarization systems frequently hallucinate content that is not supported by the source document, mainly due to noise in the training dataset.

name.justification: The paper specifically addresses issues related to abstractive text summarization.
name.quote: In this work, we propose a training objective for abstractive summarization based on rejection learning, in which the model learns whether or not to reject potentially noisy tokens.

name.justification: The research involves generating text summaries based on input documents.
name.quote: Given a source document x = (x1 , ..., xL ) with L tokens, the task is to learn a probabilistic model p̂θ (y|x) that generates a summary y = (y1 , ..., y|y| ), where yi comes from a pre-defined vocabulary V.

name.justification: The BART model is used as a baseline and also with the rejection learning and regularized decoding.
name.quote: We use pre-trained BART-LARGE as the backbone for our model.

is_contributed.justification: BART is a pre-existing model used as a baseline in the study.
is_contributed.quote: For MLE, we use the BART (Lewis et al., 2020) model.

is_executed.justification: The experiments were conducted using BART executed on GPUs.
is_executed.quote: All experiments are conducted on 4 Tesla V100 GPUs with 32GB of memory.

is_compared.justification: BART is one of the baseline models against which the proposed method is compared.
is_compared.quote: Our main contributions in this work are ... Our method significantly improves the factuality of generated summaries in automatic and human evaluations when compared to five baseline models.
